metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (Leaf area index of Mixed forest station, 2019)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the LAI measurements from the Sidaoqiao in the downstream of the Heihe integrated observatory network from June 1 to September 20 in 2019. The site was located in Ejina Banner in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The elevation is 870 m. There are 1 observation samples, around Mixed forest station (101.1335E, 41.9903N), which is about 30 m×30 m in size. Five sub-canopy nodes and one above-canopy node are arranged in each sample. 
The data is obtained from LAINet measurements; the four-steps are performed to obtain LAI: the raw data is light quantum (level 0); the daily LAI can be obtained using the software LAInet (level 1); further the invalid and null values are screened and using the 7 days moving averaged method to obtain the processed LAI (level 2); for the multi LAINet nodes observation, the averaged LAI of the nodes area is the final LAI (level 3).
The released data are the post processed LAI products and stored using *.xls format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Qu et al. (2014) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to monitor leaf area index in arid and semi-arid regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to monitor leaf area index in arid and semi-arid regions is the wireless sensor network called LAINet, which automatically collects hourly light data from multiple nodes within a study area. This data is processed to calculate daily leaf area index values, with invalid values identified and filled, and a 7-day moving average applied to reduce the impact of weather changes.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in data collection for ecosystem monitoring in inland river basins in arid and semi-arid areas?
Example.Answer: A challenge faced in data collection for ecosystem monitoring in inland river basins in arid and semi-arid areas includes the ecological environment degradation issues such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent occurrence of dust storms, as observed in basins like the Tarim River basin, Aral Sea basin, and Lake Urmia basin.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that includes energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that includes energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas is the dataset from the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin, which includes data from 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations. This dataset, available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center, comprises energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, hydrometeorological data, and vegetation and soil parameters.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific characteristics of the LAINet used for collecting leaf area index data in mixed forest stations?
Feature Specification.Answer: wireless sensor network, collects light data hourly, canopy under nodes, canopy top nodes, daily data processing, calculates leaf area index, identifies and fills invalid values, applies 7-day moving average

Feature Specification.Question: What features define the data processing levels for leaf area index data in mixed forest environments?
Feature Specification.Answer: Level0 raw hourly light data, Level1 daily LAI for each node, Level2 identification and filling of invalid values, 7-day moving average, Level3 final averaged observation value for sub-areas with multiple nodes

Feature Specification.Question: What are the defining characteristics of the observational datasets collected in oasis–desert systems?
Feature Specification.Answer: long-term observations, energy fluxes, water vapor fluxes, carbon fluxes, methane fluxes, hydrometeorology data, vegetation parameters, soil parameters, high-resolution data, half-hourly fluxes, 10-minute averages of meteorological parameters

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance system' mean in the context of data collection methods for oasis-desert systems?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system is a method used to measure and calculate turbulent fluxes of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane in an ecosystem. It involves half-hourly data acquisition to analyze the exchange of these gases and energy between the land surface and atmosphere, providing insights into oasis-desert interactions.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'oasis–desert systems' in environmental research?
Definition.Answer: Oasis–desert systems are significant in environmental research because they play a crucial role in maintaining ecological stability and agricultural productivity in arid and semi-arid regions, which support a large proportion of the population. Understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange within these systems is critical for achieving sustainable development and carbon neutrality goals.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for leaf area index using LAINet compare to the eddy covariance system and scintillometer in capturing energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis-desert systems?
Comparison.Answer: LAINet focuses on capturing leaf area index through wireless sensor networks that process light data at canopy levels, while the eddy covariance system and scintillometer are used to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data, including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, for long-term ecosystem monitoring in oasis-desert systems.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges faced by inland river basins in arid regions affect the data collection and dataset development for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange compared to leaf area index monitoring?
Comparison.Answer: Inland river basins face ecological degradation challenges like river drying and land desertification, which impact the continuity and accuracy of datasets for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, necessitating robust long-term monitoring, whereas leaf area index monitoring using LAINet may be less directly influenced but still requires careful handling of environmental variability.

Interpretation.Question: How can the use of wireless sensor networks for leaf area index measurement improve the understanding of ecosystem dynamics in mixed forest environments?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of wireless sensor networks, such as LAINet, allows for continuous, automated collection of light data at multiple nodes, which can then be processed to calculate daily leaf area index values. This method helps in capturing temporal variations and the spatial heterogeneity of leaf area index, offering insights into the ecosystem dynamics of mixed forests, such as those with poplar and tamarisk species.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise in maintaining the accuracy and reliability of long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange datasets in arid and semi-arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in maintaining the accuracy and reliability of such datasets may include ecological environment degradation, such as drying rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and dust storms. These factors can affect the data collection infrastructure and introduce variability in the measurements, necessitating robust data processing and quality control procedures to ensure data integrity.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the findings from oasis–desert systems research influence sustainable development strategies in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Findings from oasis–desert systems research can inform sustainable development strategies by providing a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. This knowledge helps maintain ecological stability and supports the socioeconomic development of oases, which is critical for achieving carbon neutrality and ecological security in arid regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for processing raw light data into daily LAI values in the context of mixed forest stations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The raw light data is processed into daily LAI values to account for variations in daily light conditions and to ensure accurate measurements by using LAINet software, which helps in recognizing and filling invalid values and applying a 7-day moving average to mitigate weather-related fluctuations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to understand the exchange of energy, water vapor, and carbon in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Understanding these exchanges is crucial for maintaining ecological stability and socio-economic development, as well as achieving carbon peaking and neutrality in these regions. It is essential for recognizing interactions between oasis and desert systems, which support the sustainable development of oases.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the degradation of the ecological environment in inland river basins located in arid and semiarid areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Factors include the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, which are particularly prevalent in many inland river basins along the Silk Road, impacting ecological stability.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of utilizing long-term observational datasets from oasis–desert ecosystems on understanding carbon exchange patterns?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing long-term observational datasets from oasis–desert ecosystems can significantly enhance the understanding of carbon exchange patterns by providing quantitative insights into how these ecosystems function as carbon sinks. This understanding is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and protecting ecological stability, which is significant for supporting the ecological security and sustainable development of these areas.

Causal Consequence.Question: How could the integration of multiple LAINet nodes' data impact the accuracy and reliability of leaf area index measurements in mixed forest stands?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating data from multiple LAINet nodes can enhance the accuracy and reliability of leaf area index measurements by averaging the nodes' observations to obtain a more comprehensive and representative value for the sub-area. This process helps in filling invalid values and smoothing out short-term weather fluctuations, thus producing a more robust dataset for ecological analysis.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes might arise from addressing the ecological degradation challenges in inland river basins with the help of datasets that include hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Addressing ecological degradation challenges in inland river basins using comprehensive datasets that include hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters could lead to improved strategies for maintaining ecological balance. It may help in developing sustainable management practices, preserving natural vegetation, and mitigating the impacts of desertification and dust storms, thereby ensuring long-term ecological and socioeconomic benefits for the affected regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it essential to understand the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems for sustainable development?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of collecting long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to achieve a quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, recognize the oasis–desert interactions, and protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in arid and semiarid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Maintaining the balance is critical to ensure the ecological security and sustainable development of oases, which are vital for supporting the majority of the population in arid regions and play a crucial role in the carbon balance and global carbon cycle.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to ensure the accuracy and reliability of leaf area index measurements in mixed forest stations using wireless sensor networks?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The leaf area index measurements in mixed forest stations are obtained using the LAINet wireless sensor network, which captures light data hourly at each node. The raw data undergoes processing with LAINet software to calculate daily LAI values, followed by invalid value identification and imputation. A 7-day moving average is applied to mitigate weather-induced variability, and the average of multiple nodes in an observation sub-area is used as the final observation value.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in establishing and maintaining long-term observational datasets in arid and semiarid river basins, and how are these datasets made accessible for research purposes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Long-term observational datasets in arid and semiarid river basins are established by setting up land surface flux and meteorological stations. These datasets include energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, along with hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters. The data are collected, processed, and subjected to quality control, then archived and made freely available for research purposes through platforms like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the continuous monitoring of leaf area index in mixed forest stations in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of a wireless sensor network known as LAINet allows for the continuous acquisition of light data at each node, which is then processed to calculate daily leaf area index values. This technological setup facilitates the continuous monitoring of leaf area index in mixed forest stations.

Enablement.Question: How do data processing techniques enable the identification and filling of invalid values in environmental datasets?
Enablement.Answer: Data processing techniques involve utilizing LAINet software to process raw observation data, calculate daily leaf area index, and identify and fill invalid values. The process also includes a 7-day moving average to mitigate the impact of weather variations on LAI calculation.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do long-term observational datasets enhance the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Long-term observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems provide crucial data on energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, along with auxiliary hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters. These datasets are indispensable for quantitatively understanding the interactions and ensuring ecological stability in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Expectation.Question: Why is it expected that maintaining a balance between oasis and desert systems is crucial for achieving sustainable oasis development?
Expectation.Answer: It is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems to achieve sustainable oasis development because understanding the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these ecosystems supports ecological security and sustainable development. This balance is significant for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area.

Expectation.Question: What challenges are anticipated in collecting long-term observational datasets in arid and semiarid inland river basins?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face challenges such as ecological environment degradation, including the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These factors make long-term data collection challenging.

Expectation.Question: Why is it necessary to utilize a combination of data collection methods involving both artificial and natural systems for understanding oasis–desert interactions?
Expectation.Answer: A combination of data collection methods from artificial and natural systems is necessary to achieve a comprehensive understanding of oasis–desert interactions because they provide long-term data on energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, along with hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, which are crucial for recognizing these interactions and ensuring ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you believe the LAINet system is in capturing accurate leaf area index data in mixed forest environments?
Judgmental.Answer: The LAINet system is designed to automatically acquire light data across multiple nodes to calculate daily leaf area index values. The system further processes this data to remove invalid values and averages results across nodes to provide a comprehensive observation, suggesting a robust approach to capturing accurate data in mixed forest environments.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the challenges faced in maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems for sustainable development?
Judgmental.Answer: Maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems presents significant challenges due to ecological environment degradation issues such as drying rivers, vegetation degradation, and increased desertification, especially in inland river basins along the Silk Road. Long-term and comprehensive observational datasets are critical to address these challenges and support sustainable development.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how comprehensive are the observational datasets available from oasis–desert systems for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange?
Judgmental.Answer: The observational datasets from oasis–desert systems are quite comprehensive, comprising long-term data on energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, along with auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. These datasets are collected using advanced methods like eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, which provide valuable insights into ecosystem interactions.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods can effectively measure the energy and water vapor exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems.
Assertion.Answer: Data collection involves using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data, as well as automatic weather stations that provide hydrometeorological data at a 10-minute average period. These methods enable detailed and accurate monitoring of energy and water vapor exchanges in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection techniques utilized for monitoring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection techniques involve using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer for acquiring half-hourly turbulent flux data. Additionally, hydrometeorological data, including radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles, are observed from automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period. Groundwater table data and auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters are also part of the data collection.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify the challenges faced in data collection for ecological studies in inland river basins within arid and semi-arid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges in data collection for ecological studies in these regions include the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent occurrences of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe potential datasets that could be utilized for studying land surface flux and meteorological conditions in arid regions of western China.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include the observational data from the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, which consist of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations, along with hydrometeorological data and vegetation and soil parameters. These datasets are freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center, with data collected from 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations established since 2012.
